title: Tracking Six Legs Of Trouble; Scientists Grudgingly Respect A Prolific Beetle From China

body: The city's property tax rate, frozen for a decade, will rise by 18 percent on Jan. 1 under an agreement announced yesterday between the Bloomberg administration and City Council leaders. ''It's a painful measure,'' the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, said in announcing the agreement in the Red Room at City Hall shortly after 4:30 p.m. The deal
title: CITY BUDGET DEAL INCLUDES 18% RISE IN PROPERTY TAXES

body: Somewhere in their 30-year career as anonymous, independent, arty rockers, the Residents stopped smirking. When they started, they were prepunk do-it-yourselfers, releasing homemade albums that mocked recent pop and rock with jokey lyrics and singsong dissonances. The Residents, who are based in San Francisco, have never shown their faces to
title: ROCK REVIEW; Masked Cranks Take On America

title: As Closings Loom, Firefighters Try to Rally Neighbors

body: Eight fire companies would be disbanded as part of a $51 million reduction in the Fire Department's $1 billion budget. The closings would save the department $10.8 million, but could not take place before a 45-day public review. The companies slated for closing are: in Brooklyn, Engine 204 in Cobble Hill, Engine 212 in Greenpoint, Engine 278 in
title: THE MAYOR'S BUDGET PLAN: SPENDING; Fire Department

body: Banks are aggressively promoting free checking accounts. But some customers are discovering that free often comes at a price. While customers no longer have to pay fees if their balances drop below a minimum, many who open these accounts often end up paying more in other charges, like those for bouncing checks or using automated teller machines.
title: Checking Is Free, but the Profits Are Hefty

body: New York City's vibrant arts scene is often portrayed as an unalloyed good, economically as well as creatively. title: Report Says Artists' Arrival Can Push Out Neighbors

Those were the heady final years of the 20th century,
title: URBAN TACTICS; Latest Exit to Brooklyn

body: New York City is a land of captive trees, whether you think of the nearly natural expanses of Central Park and Prospect Park or the private gardens that thrive on terraces and rooftops. But to an Asian longhorned beetle, wood is wood, and with 5.2 million trees, New York has a lot of wood to offer. Half of its trees grow on private property. The
title: The Uninvited Pest

body: More than half of the estimated five million trees in New York City grow behind walls, guarded by doormen or locked doors. It is the job of Kittzie Gonzalez and Laura Osanitch, inspectors for the United States Department of Agriculture, to check each one for signs of the Asian longhorned beetle, one of the most destructive arboreal pests to reach
title: A Devastating Invader Behind Closed Doors; Asian Beetles May Be on Private Property, But Inspectors Often Can't Get In to Check

body: The problem facing octogenarian bank robbers is that they don't move as fast as they used to. That apparently was the case with John Anthony Sadowy's holdup-gone-wrong at the Greenpoint Savings Bank on Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens. The police say Mr. Sadowy, 82, got away with $3,635 on the afternoon of Sept. 26 after showing a female
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; Taking The Money And Not Exactly Running

body: WHEN David Graham, a 38-year-old painter, gave up a studio carved out of an old diner in Williamsburg in 1997, 6 years into a 10-year lease to spend a year in Montreal, he figured he would have little difficulty duplicating it when he returned a year later. ''There was still a lot of space available, so I didn't think it would be a big deal,'' he
title: Artists Canvassing for Space

body: A wood-munching beetle that has destroyed thousands of trees in New York City and Chicago has been found in New Jersey, causing concern that its damage may spread. Federal and state agricultural officials said today that they had found the Asian longhorned beetles on Thursday inside 98 trees on a nine-acre plot here among apartment and office
title: Tree-Munching Asian Beetles Are Discovered in Jersey City

title: How Hipness Moves

title: Priests Seek to Assert Rights and Fight Church Abuse Policy

body: For the last 20 years or so, Long Island City, Queens, has been on the verge of being ''discovered'' by the same combination of art and real estate that put SoHo and Williamsburg on the map. The talk began in 1981 with the opening of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center on Jackson Avenue. A flurry of converted artist studios and renovated brownstones
title: For Art: Destination, Queens; The Modern's Relocation Energizes Long Island City

body: THIS one deals with life in our new world, which may or may not be brave. It starts with Lisa Nussbaum deciding that a dinner cruise on New York's waters would be a splendid way to celebrate a year of being together with her boyfriend. It was also, she thought, a way for her to signal a fresh emotional start one year after the terrorist attacks.
title: NYC; It's Called Terror For a Reason

body: THE seriousness of fall, with its early twilights, overbooked restaurants and new television shows, has descended, and the simple, enduring rituals of city life that seemed impertinent in the heat are reviving. In other words, brunch is back. The quintessential New York brunch involves a deceptively simple triumvirate: bagel, cream cheese and lox.
title: So Pink, So New York

body: SEVERAL fast-emerging artists in New York have been generating the kind of creative heat that tends to catch the art world's attention -- and lately has. title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; New Yorkers Now, Their Gifts Were Nurtured in Texas

title: At House Museums, Instructive Vignettes From the Past

body: A factory worker was crushed to death Wednesday night when an 8,000-pound stack of recycled paper collapsed and struck him in the head, the police said yesterday. No one else was injured. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Crushed In Accident

title: On the Party Whirl in Tinseltown North

title: Homeless Man Slain

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; To Bikers, an Open Door Is No Invitation

title: ROCK REVIEW; Singing About Frustration, Some Strain, No Self-Pity

body: Robert Menje leaned against a blue garage door at Shea Stadium yesterday and held up an autographed baseball so he could examine the precise signatures in ballpoint pen. title: BASEBALL; With Deadline in Play, The Fans Feel Squeezed

title: In the Big City, Smaller Banks Find a Sizable Niche

body: It is a little-known fact of social science that, above a certain temperature, the will to be fashionable fails. title: If You Can't Stand the Heat, Get Out of the Suit

body: IN 1987, at 19, an accident left Russell Hopkins of Bushwick, Brooklyn, a quadriplegic. title: Living Large In a Small Room

body: After 140 years at the bottom of the sea, the 160-ton gun turret of the Monitor is to be lifted into daylight soon off Cape Hatteras, N.C., in the culmination of a five-year, $14 million effort to save the famous ironclad. title: Retrieval Efforts Aim to Bring Ironclad Monitor Back to Life

title: Piece by Piece, the Civil War's Monitor Is Pulled From the Atlantic's Depths

title: PUBLIC LIVES; The Happiest Feet Are on His Legs

body: WHAT was once a tidal wave of conversions of New York City rental buildings to condominiums or co-ops slowed drastically a decade ago, but a trickle of conversions continues. title: Conversions From Rentals Trickle On

body: Robert M. Morgenthau, the venerable Manhattan district attorney, has a long history of reaching into other counties to take on politically charged cases. title: Bill, Meant for Morgenthau, Would Restrict Jurisdiction

body: ON May 28, I taught my last class at Bard High School Early College, which is located in a large, rectangular, 1960-ish public school building in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. title: URBAN TACTICS; Not-Quite-Instant-Message

body: For many students, the last year or two of high school feel like a waste. Students are preoccupied with SAT's, worried about getting into college, buffeted by the social jousting of the teenage years and eager to move on. Some pile on advanced placement courses. Others do as little work as possible. To a few educators, the solution to the
title: A Year of Squeezing 6 Into 4; Students Embrace City's Early-College Experiment

body: It happened to the pizza slice. It happened to the subway token. It looks as if the bagel is next. At H&H, New York's flagship bagel shop, the price has teetered at the 95-cent precipice for almost two years, gradually rising from 15 cents (as best as H&H employees can recall) when the shop opened in 1972. So it seems inevitable that the first $1
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Carbo Loading: On the Brink of the Dollar Bagel

body: Tucked into Mayor Michael Bloomberg's inaugural address was an eight-word promise that, if fulfilled, could greatly enhance the quality of life in this city and add an unexpected dimension to the Bloomberg mayoralty. ''We will bring new life to our waterfront,'' Mr. Bloomberg said, and while no details have emerged, the pledge itself was exciting
title: Reclaiming New York's Waterfront

body: JOEY RAMONE, who died of lymphoma last year, might have been tickled to know he has simultaneous birthday parties tonight. title: Then, Now: New Rock City

body: For more than 10 years, the Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests was little more than a loose support group of men and women who gathered in one another's homes to share tears, traumatic memories and legal advice. Their stories rarely made it beyond their living rooms, and members say they grew used to being ignored or rebuffed by the Roman
title: Victims' Group Uses Spotlight to Seek Changes in Law

body: Time Equities Inc., one of the largest co-op and condominium converters in the city, has embarked on its smallest conversion project ever -- turning a four-story red brick row house into a condo at 102 Clay Street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. title: POSTINGS: 4 Stories, 4 Units on Clay Street in Greenpoint; A Row House in Brooklyn Is Turning Into Condos

title: URBAN TACTICS; A Writer Baits His Fishhooks With Urban Grit

body: ANNE LINDEBERG'S first housing stop in Manhattan after she arrived from Minneapolis in 1999 was a friend's studio apartment on East Houston Street. Now Ms. Lindeberg and her sister
title: Williamsburg: More Housing, Higher Prices

body: This summer, New York plans to deploy two weapons in its battle with Asian longhorned beetles, a fight that has already resulted in the destruction of 4,623 trees since the beetles were first discovered locally in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 1996. Under the new strategy, 80,000 trees across the city will be treated with injections of insecticide by
title: When Beetles Start Chewing, City Bugs Will Be Listening

body: An early morning fire ripped through eight adjoining row houses in Greenpoint yesterday, putting 22 families out of their homes, the authorities said. Although none of the residents were injured, seven firefighters sustained minor injuries fighting the blaze, which started about 3:30 in a row house on Diamond Street near Norman Avenue. Before the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Fire Displaces 22 Families

body: RENT for a 7-by-5-foot sleeping cubicle at the Andrews Hotel, a century-old flophouse at 197 Bowery: $9 a night. Rent for the penthouse in a renovated building across the street and down the block at 214 Bowery: $5,500 a month. The Bowery is gentrifying. And as the six-lane, median-stripped, 19-block-long roadway that once meandered past Peter
title: On the New Bowery, Down and Out Mix With Up and Coming

body: No one has ever seen a State Assembly district line drawn on the ground. And yet they can seem as real as fences. At a recent round of redistricting hearings, people from all over the state fought to move their lines, citing reasons as diverse as racial balance and the omission of a particular park or school. But the tiny neighborhood of Vinegar
title: Enclave Links Its Political Fate to Its Rich History

body: New York has bestowed names on many things over the years. There is the New York minute and the Bronx cheer, the Manhattan cocktail and the Waldorf salad. Even Mount Rushmore is named after a New York lawyer, Charles E. Rushmore, who owned mining property in the area. With this in mind, there is a chance that a new fitness routine might be named
title: Tunnel Vision; Next to This Event, the Turnstile High Jump Is Easy

body: IT took only one morning, Sept. 11, to change the image of ferry service from a pleasant anachronism to a sensible and urgently needed means of mass transit. With tunnels crippled, roads blocked and bridges closed, tens of thousands of workers and residents moved on a nimble fleet over natural, impervious and far-reaching highways. And many have
title: Launching a Flotilla of Ferry Terminals

body: It's possible to listen to music and hear only patterns. But is it possible to listen to patterns and hear only music? On Thursday night four electronic acts came to Warsaw -- in Greenpoint, Brooklyn -- searching for musical values in a mathematical maze of patterns. There were two D.J.'s, Mira Calix and Keith Tenniswood, and two computer-based
title: POP REVIEW; Listening To Patterns: Do the Math

author: George Packer is the author of ''Blood of the Liberals.'' His last feature article for the magazine was on Schools Chancellor Harold Levy.
body: If you've ever left a bag of clothes outside the Salvation Army or given to a local church drive, chances are that you've dressed an African. All over Africa, people are wearing what Americans once wore and no longer want. Visit the continent and you'll find faded remnants of secondhand clothing in the strangest of places. The ''Let's Help Make
title: How Susie Bayer's T-Shirt Ended Up on Yusuf Mama's Back

body: Stefanya, a doleful, aging Pole, sat on a milk crate early yesterday morning in Brooklyn, vowing that she would work for no less than $10 an hour. ''I forgot tonight was Passover,'' Stefanya said through an interpreter, noticing that the bakery next door was closed. ''I think they'll use their regular women today. They work you so hard for Passover
title: Brooklyn Poles and Jews Refashion Old World Ties

body: FINDING that just-right combination of affordable and suitable artists' space in Westchester can be a formidable undertaking. And when an artist finally discovers space that fits the bill, there is always the worry
title: In the Region/Westchester; Helping Artists Find Affordable and Suitable Space

body: In less than two hours, criminals robbed or tried to rob four banks yesterday morning in Brooklyn and Queens. Last year, roughly one bank in New York City was robbed each business day, according to the F.B.I. So far, the police do not see any links between any of yesterday's robberies. More than $6,000 in all was taken, said Jerry Varson, a Police
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Robbers Strike Four Banks

title: Oh, How the Garden Does Groan; As the Knicks Wilt, New York Feels Yet Another Loss

body: GREENPOINT may occupy a position in the geographic center of New York, but it's a world away from the rest of the city. Tucked into the northern tip of Brooklyn, bounded by the East River to the west and Newtown Creek to the north, and not easily accessible by public transportation, this resolutely working-class neighborhood of Polish immigrants
title: $25 AND UNDER; A Red and White Standout in the Greenpoint Borscht Belt

body: A LOOK at some unfinished business: Literary New York Those admirably optimistic folks trying to select a book for people to read in New York -- where nobody agrees on anything -- might enhance their chances of success if they modified their mission. They could recommend a book for each month, and maybe placate every ethnic, religious and special
title: Metro Metters; A City's Books And Itineraries Of Politicians

body: It has been here for at least a decade, quietly chewing its way through the city's beloved maples and elms, leaving barren neighborhoods and parks in its wake. First discovered in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, it appeared in Queens, Long Island and Manhattan, before finally, disappointingly, wreaking its telltale damage within the stone walls of Central
title: Trying to Catch Up To a Hungry Beetle; Invading Tree Pest Fights Tough

body: The Asian longhorned beetle may be new to Central Park, where two maple trees infested by the voracious insect were recently discovered. But five miles away as the crow flies, residents of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, are all too familiar with the insect, its appetite and the havoc it can create. In 1996, Greenpoint's maple trees were found riddled with
title: Brooklyn Neighborhood Recalls Battle With Pest

body: BRYAN BULLETT, a 30-year-old resident of the East Village, was laid off from a software company last year and instead of hunting for a new job has opted to produce and play guitar full time in a struggling new-wave-influenced band, Playdate. He makes ends meet by bartending. And in his free time he travels to Brooklyn to attend rock shows, hit the
title: Where the Girls Are, and the Commute's Easy

body: One man died and three others were injured yesterday when fire broke out in a building in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. A Police Department spokeswoman, Officer Cheryl Cox, said the identities of the victims were being withheld last night. Firefighters were called at 12:10 p.m. to a one-story industrial building at 818 Meeker Avenue, and had extinguished
title: Man Dies in Brooklyn Fire

body: NEVER mind a melting pot. Last Tuesday it was so cold that New York was a Slurpee machine. Or maybe it was a tossed salad, given the disparate events that drew highly specific young people to big parties on the Upper East and Lower East Sides. One event, the Winter Ball benefit at the Museum of the City of New York, was a celebration of the young
title: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; Two Parties, Poles Apart

body: Fulfilling the long-held fears of city officials and arborphiles, the Asian longhorned beetle, a voracious insect that has threatened vast swaths of trees in New York, Chicago and Europe, has for the first time surfaced among the prized maples of Central Park. Two infected trees, one Norway maple and one sugar maple, were discovered within a nature
title: Trees at Risk From Invader With Appetite

body: Community groups, tired of battling large institutions over plans to build high-rises in western Harlem and in Morningside Heights, are seeking to rezone the entire area covered by Community Board 9 to limit the number of tall buildings. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS; Trying to Tame Towers That Big Institutions Seek

body: MUSIC clubs have an image as the opposite of swimming pools: you want to enter them only after you have eaten. Food and wine have never been part of the program on the live music scene. title: The Music Cooks and the Food Sings

body: CHARLES MONAGHAN was in bed reading a mystery when his phone rang around midnight one night last May. Earlier that evening, he and his wife, Jennifer, had stopped by their local political club, the Central Brooklyn Independent Democrats, to vote on its endorsements for the Democratic primary. After dinner, the couple had settled into bed in their
title: The First Hurrah
